November 7, 2012. Retrieved November 8, 2012</ref>
==2014 election== ''[[The Washington Post]]'' said in July 2012 that the Tea Party "is no longer the rising tsunami it appeared to be in 2010. Largely gone are the disorderly rallies, colonial-era costumes and fixations on fringe issues, such as the provenance of the president's birth certificate. Instead, the movement has retooled into a loosely organized network of field operations that, as in Texas, pushes Republicans toward more strident conservative positions and candidates, while supplying ground troops across the country for candidates and big-money conservative groups, such as the [[Club for Growth]] and [[Americans for Prosperity]]."<ref name="retool">{{cite news|last=Blackmon |first=Douglas |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/tea-party-retools-itself-pushing-republicans-toward-more-strident-conservative-positions/2012/07/30/gJQAGuG1KX_print.html|title=Tea party retools as network of field operatives, keeps pushing GOP rightward| newspaper=The Washington Post |date=July 30, 2012 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
Tea Party members now tell stories of mailing literature from their laundry rooms, manning phone banks, knocking on doors,<ref name="retool"/> and driving over 34,000 miles in their cars to build support for legislation.<ref name="msnbc.msn.com"/> The [[Tea Party Patriots]] now offer free, on-demand, online grassroots training programs.<ref>[http://teapartytraining.org/ TEA PARTY TRAINING POWERED BY THE LEADERSHIP INSTITUTE] The Tea Party Patriots. Retrieved August 20, 2012.</ref> The Tea Party has partnered with seemingly unlikely groups, such as the [[NAACP]] and the [[Sierra Club]].<ref name="csmonitor.com"/>
In the 2014 elections in [[Texas]], the Tea Party made large gains, with numerous Tea Party favorites being elected into office, like [[Dan Patrick (politician)|Dan Patrick]] as [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas|Lieutenant Governor]],<ref name="Holdssway">{{cite news | last1=Fernandez | first1=Manny | title=Lieutenant Governor Loses Texas Runoff as Tea Party Holds Sway | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/28/us/politics/tea-party-favorite-beats-lieutenant-governor-in-texas.html | date=May 27, 2014 | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=April 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>Koppel, Nathan (January 21, 2015) – [https://www.wsj.com/articles/texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick-moves-quickly-to-advance-conservative-agenda-1421883867 "Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Moves Quickly to Advance Conservative Agenda"]. ''The Wall Street Journal''. Retrieved April 2, 2015.</ref> [[Ken Paxton]] as [[Attorney General of Texas|Attorney General]],<ref name="Holdssway"/><ref name="Grissom">Grissom, Brandi. [http://www.texastribune.org/2014/05/28/tea-party-conservatives-win-top-gop-runoff-contest/ Tea Party Conservatives Win Top GOP Runoff Contests], ''[[Texas Tribune]]'', May 28, 2014. Retrieved April 2, 2015.</ref> in addition to numerous other candidates.<ref name="Grissom"/>
==2015 elections== In the [[Kentucky gubernatorial election, 2015|2015 Kentucky gubernatorial election]], [[Matt Bevin]], a Tea Party favorite who challenged [[Mitch McConnell]] in the Republican primary in the [[United States Senate election in Kentucky, 2014|2014 Kentucky Senate election]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Trinko|first=Katrina|title=Kentucky's Ted Cruz?|url=http://nationalreview.com/article/354652/kentuckys-ted-cruz-katrina-trinko|accessdate=November 5, 2015|newspaper=National Review|date=July 29, 2013}}</ref> won with over 52% of the vote, despite fears that he was too extreme for the state.<ref name="Sweat">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/31/us/politics/gop-eyes-kentucky-governorship-but-candidate-is-making-the-party-sweat.html|title=G.O.P. Eyes Kentucky Governorship, but Candidate Is Making the Party Sweat|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/05/us/kentuckys-next-governormatt-bevin-rode-in-on-outsider-status.html?_r=0|title=Kentucky’s Next Governor, Matt Bevin, Rode In on Outsider Status|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/04/us/republican-wins-governors-race-in-kentucky.html|title=Matt Bevin, Republican, Wins Governor’s Race in Kentucky|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 8, 2015}}</ref> Bevin is the second Republican in 44 years to be [[Governor of Kentucky]].<ref name="Sweat"/>
==2016 presidential election== The [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|2016 Republican presidential primary]] featured three U.S. Senators, [[Ted Cruz]], [[Rand Paul]], [[Marco Rubio]], whose elections to the U.S. Senate were broadly attributed to Tea Party movement support. The ultimate winner of the Republican presidential primary, [[Donald Trump]], praised the U.S. [[Tea Party movement]] throughout his 2016 campaign.<ref name="auto1">[http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/29/politics/donald-trump-tea-party-nashville/ "Donald Trump courts tea party at Nashville straw poll," By MJ Lee, CNN, August 29, 2015], retrieved December 1, 2016.</ref> In August 2015, Trump told a Tea Party gathering in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] that "The tea party people are incredible people. These are people who work hard and love the country and they get beat up all the time by the media."<ref name="auto1"/> In a January 2016 [[CNN]] poll at the beginning of the [[2016 Republican primary]], Trump led all Republican candidates modestly among self-identified Tea Party voters with 37 percent supporting Trump and 34 percent supporting Ted Cruz.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/26/politics/donald-trump-ted-cruz-polling/ "CNN/ORC Donald Trump Poll: Donald Trump dominates GOP field at 41%," by Jennifer Agiesta, CNN, January 26, 2016], retrieved December 1, 2016.</ref>
==Ground game and Get Out The Vote (GOTV) efforts== [[File:ScottWalker(pol).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Scott Walker at Marquette University conference, 2007]]
===Tea Party ground game/GOTV before 2012=== Tea Party activists nationwide made a mass pilgrimage to the Bay State to support [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]]'s unlikely campaign and ultimate win over Democrat [[Martha Coakley]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Van Sack |first= Jessica|url=http://bostonherald.com/news/politics/view/20100119epic_battle_ends_at_the_polls_today_eyes_of_nation_on_mass_as_voters_decide_on_scott_brown_martha_coakley|title=Amazing Senate battle heads to the finish line|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Democrats have said as late as September 2010 that the Tea Party could not match their ground game and was mostly hype. The Democrats have the advantage in better organization, an older volunteer organization and personal connections between volunteers and voters.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dickerson |first=John|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2010/09/obama_unleashed.html|title=Obama Unleashed|publisher=Slate|date=September 2, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref>
On November 2, 2010, [[Fox News]] reported that the Democrats did not dispute expectations that they would lose the House, and that their vaunted campaign operation faced a less polished ground game infused with the energy of the new Tea Party.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/11/02/voters-poised-punish-democrats-ballot-box/|title=Control of Congress at Stake on Election Day|publisher=FOX News|date=November 2, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref> The Tea Party helped deliver to Democrats what President Obama called a "shellacking" in the mid-term elections.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jackson |first=David|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/theoval/post/2010/11/obamas-shellacking----how-badly-will-it-bruise-his-agenda/1#.UC9gViqF-K4|title=Obama's 'shellacking' – how badly will it bruise his agenda|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 4, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref> On November 10, 2010, [[FreedomWorks]] announced the national rollout of "FreedomConnect", which they touted as a "grassroots action center that will revolutionize the ways in which FreedomWorks members, 9/12ers and tea party groups across the country communicate and organize in 2011 and beyond".<ref>{{cite news|last=Bodnar |first=Jacqueline|url=http://www.freedomworks.org/press-releases/freedomworks-launches-tea-party-action-center-“fre|title=FreedomWorks Launches Tea Party Action Center "FreedomConnect" In Ohio|publisher=FreedomWorks|date=November 16, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref>
===Challenge of the ground game for the Tea Party in the 2012 election cycle=== The ground game was considered to be a major challenge for Tea Party candidates in several important contests in 2012, including Wisconsin's recall election of Gov. [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Carey |first=Nick |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/47641406/ns/politics/t/wisconsin-recall-tests-conservatives-ground-game/#.UC7HQiqF-K4 |title=Wisconsin recall tests conservative's ground game. |publisher=NBCNews.com |date=June 1, 2012 |accessdate=August 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725231039/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/47641406/ns/politics/t/wisconsin-recall-tests-conservatives-ground-game/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hamby |first=Peter |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/05/politics/wisconsin-recall/index.html|title=Walker's fate in Wisconsin comes down to ground game.|publisher=CNN.com |date=June 1, 2012 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> and the Texas GOP Senate primary race between "establishment" candidate Lt. Gov. [[David Dewhurst]] and Tea Party favorite [[Ted Cruz]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Fikac |first=Peggy |url=http://www.chron.com/news/politics/article/Ad-war-costly-but-campaigns-ground-games-will-3725445.php|title=Ground games will be key for Cruz, Dewhurst.| newspaper=Houston Chronicle |date=July 23, 2012 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
Early in the election cycle, Democratic allies had expressed confidence in the strength of their own ground game. In September 2011, [[Teamsters]] President [[James P. Hoffa|Jimmy Hoffa]] delivering a speech to introduce President Obama to the gathered crowd, said "We got to keep an eye on the battle that we face: The war on workers. And you see it everywhere, it is the Tea Party.... We're going to win that war.... President Obama, this is your army.... We are ready to march. Let's take these sons of bitches out and give America back to an America where we belong."<ref>{{cite news|last=Crabtree |first=Susan |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2011/09/hoffa-lets-take-these-sons-of-bitches-out.php|title=Hoffa: 'Let's Take These Sons Of Bitches Out!'|publisher=TPMDC |date=September 5, 2011|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Similarly, Organized Labor in Wisconsin hoped its ground game would give it the edge.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nwlaborpress.org/2012/05/wisconsin-9/|title=Anti-union Wisconsin governor faces June 5 recall|publisher=nwLaborPress.org |date=May 29, 2012|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> According to [[Karl Rove]], Democratic Party Chair [[Debbie Wasserman Schultz]] also boasted on [[CNN]] in May that the Wisconsin recall would be the "dry run we need of our massive, significant dynamic grass-roots presidential campaign".<ref>{{cite news|last=Fikac |first=Peggy |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303665904577450533294600706?mod=WSJ_Opinion_LEADTop|title=Rove: Wisconsin and the GOP Ground Game.|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=June 6, 2012 |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
When challenging GOP "establishment" opponents, the Tea Party faced opposing ground games of various size and sophistication. In Texas, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst hired "ground game expert" Kevin Lindley, who had run Gov. [[Rick Perry]]'s campaigns,<ref>{{cite news|last=Root|first=Jay|url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-politics/2012-elections/ricks-perry-senate-race/|title=Risks For Perry In Senate Race|publisher=Texas Weekly |date=July 13, 2011|accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref> while in Indiana [[Richard Lugar]] no longer lived in the state and developed a reputation for being out of touch with voters there.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Elections/Senate/2012/0509/In-Richard-Lugar-defeat-a-tea-party-road-map-for-revamping-Washington |title=In Richard Lugar defeat, a tea party road map for revamping Washington? |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |date=May 9, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2015}} The '''Expatriate Party of New Zealand''' is an unregistered [[political party]] that seeks to represent people who consider themselves [[New Zealanders]] but who do not reside in New Zealand. It contested one electorate, but not the party vote, at the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]].
== Policies == According to the party's Facebook page, the Expatriate Party seeks "to provide representation for, and to promote fairness in the treatment of all members of the mobile global workforce who identify as New Zealanders, irrespective of where they live or their residency or citizenship status."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pg/expatsnz/about/?mt_nav=1|title=The Expats - NZ Political Party - About|last=|first=|date=|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref>
The party put forward several policies during their 2014 campaign. The main policy for that election was fairer rules to allow New Zealanders to become Australian permanent residents, with the rights to services such as healthcare that this would bring.<ref name="NZHerald-18July">{{cite web|last=Cheng |first=Derek |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11295242 |title=Expat Party taking run at Parliament |publisher=New Zealand Herald |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> However, the party made clear it did not intend to seek access to unemployment benefits.<ref name="HeraldSun">{{cite web|last=Hamblin |first=Andrea |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/new-zealanders-living-in-australia-are-demanding-rights-and-government-assistance/story-fni0fiyv-1226991538497?nk=6e207ee8fc1bd50fe2b9d601a6bb7d01 |title=New Zealanders living in Australia are demanding rights and government assistance |publisher=Herald Sun |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="IBH">{{cite web|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/559421/20140717/new-zealand-australia-kiwi-rights-social-services.htm#.U83UEbFqNF-|title=New Zealanders Fight for Rights in Australia with Expat Party's Race to Parliament|last=Su|first=Reissa|date=18 July 2014|website=|publisher=International Business Times|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> It also supported reforms to New Zealand law regarding whether and how expatriates may participate in New Zealand elections (including studying the introduction of [[electronic voting]]); reduction of regulation and taxation (which it considers a disincentive for expatriates to remain connected to New Zealand); and stronger social and economic ties with New Zealand's traditional allies.<ref name="TheExpatHub">{{cite web|url=http://www.theexpathub.com/expatriate-party-new-zealand-plans-fight-voting-law/5969/ |title=The Expatriate Party of New Zealand plans to fight Voting Law |publisher=The Expat Hub |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="partywebsite">{{cite web|url=http://expatparty.org/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427023412/http://expatparty.org/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 April 2014|title=Expatriate Party of New Zealand website|accessdate=22 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== 2014 election == The party spokespeople were Grant Cheesman and Nick Teulon, both of whom were [[New Zealander Australian|New Zealand-born residents of Australia]].<ref name="NZHerald-18July"/><ref name="TheExpatHub"/> By August 2014, the party had announced that it had sufficient numbers to register as a political party in New Zealand, which would have allowed it to contest the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 election]].<ref name="registryapplication">{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=508010872662552&set=a.430068563790117.1073741830.425216270942013&type=1 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140726124606/https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=508010872662552&set=a.430068563790117.1073741830.425216270942013&type=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 July 2014 |title=Expat Party Facebook page |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/expatsnz/photos/a.430068563790117.1073741830.425216270942013/513965032067136/?type=3|title=The Expats - NZ Political Party|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> However, the registration process was not completed before Writ Day due to issues in verifying registered members, leaving the party unable to contest the party vote.<ref name="registryfailure">{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/10408315/Expat-Party-won-t-be-registered |title=Expat Party won't be registered |date=21 August 2014 |accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> The Expatriate Party ran one electorate candidate at the 2014 elections. Vicky Rose contested the Maori Electorate of [[Ikaroa-Rāwhiti]],<ref name="registryfailure" /> receiving 70 votes, which was 0.32% of the electorate vote; Rose came last of the six candidates.
== 2014-2017 == During 2014, the party stated it did not rule out the possibility of participating in Australian elections in the future.<ref name="SMH-16July">{{cite web|last=Flitton |first=Daniel |url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/kiwis-fight-for-social-service-rights-in-australia-20140716-ztkji.html |title=Kiwis fight for social service rights in Australia |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald |date=16 July 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> However, it did not contest the [[Australian federal election, 2016|2016 Australian election]].
== 2017 election and current status == On 8 February 2017, the party announced on their Facebook page that they had talked with the Electoral Commission about enrolling for the 2017 election, and another post on 3 March stated it has applied for broadcasting funding.<ref name="2017fundingapp">{{cite web|url=https://m.facebook.com/expatsnz/photos/a.430068563790117.1073741830.425216270942013/979640152166286/?type=3&source=48|title=The Expats - NZ Political Party|accessdate=3 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elections.org.nz/news-media/2017-variation-broadcasting-allocation-decision-released|title=2017 Variation Broadcasting Allocation Decision Released|work=Electoral Commission|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en}}</ref> However, in August 2017 the party announced they had not achieved the numbers needed to register the party and that it would not contest the election.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/expatsnz/posts/1085895501540750|title=The Expats - NZ Political Party|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-23}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official site|http://expatparty.org/}}{{Dead link|date=March 2017}} * [https://www.facebook.com/expatsnz/ Official Facebook page]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{Executive}} A '''first minister''' is one of a variety of terms for the leader of a government [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]], which is a term currently used to refer to the political leader of a devolved national government, such as the [[Devolution in the United Kingdom|devolved administrations]] of [[First Minister of Scotland|Scotland]], [[First Minister of Wales|Wales]], and [[Executive Office (Northern Ireland)|Northern Ireland]], or of a dependent territory.
==Canada== {{Further|Premier (Canada)}} In [[Canada]], "''first ministers''" is a collective term that refers to all of the Canadian first [[Minister of the Crown|ministers of the Crown]], otherwise known as [[Head of Government|heads of government]], including the [[Prime Minister of Canada]] and the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|provincial and territorial]] [[premier]]s. It is used in such formulae as "[[first ministers' meetings]]".
In [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], the [[Inuit]] self-governing region of [[Nunatsiavut]] provides for a first minister responsible to the Nunatsiavut Assembly.
==Norway== The [[head of government of Norway]] was called ''first minister'' ({{Lang-no|førstestatsråd}}) between 1814 and 1873, while it was in [[personal union]] [[Union between Sweden and Norway|with Sweden]]. In 1893, 12 years prior to the [[Dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden in 1905|dissolution of the union]], it was changed to [[prime minister]] (''statsminister'').
==United Kingdom== In the United Kingdom, the term ''first minister'' was once used interchangeably with [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|prime minister]], such as when [[Winston Churchill]] stated: "I did not become His Majesty's First Minister so that I might oversee the liquidation of the British Empire!"
Nowadays, the term is used to describe the leaders of the [[Devolution in the United Kingdom|devolved]] governments of [[Scotland]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/About/People |title=About: People: Who runs the Scottish Government |publisher=[[Scottish Government]] |date=10 March 2014 |accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> [[Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]]. See
*[[List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies#Countries of the United Kingdom|List of first ministers]] *[[First Minister of Scotland]] *[[First Minister of Wales]] *[[First Minister and deputy First Minister]] (Northern Ireland)
==Other== In [[Germany]], the first minister in the federal states is known as the [[Ministerpräsident]].
In [[Malaysia]], the first minister for each state with a Malay ruler is known as the [[Menteri Besar]].
[[George Cadle Price|George Price]] held the office of First Minister of [[British Honduras]] from 1961 until 1964, when it became self-governing and the title was changed to [[Premier]]. He continued as Premier after the [[colony]] changed its names to [[Belize]], and then as [[Prime Minister]] after Belize gained full independence in 1981.

{{Globalize/US|date=June 2011}} [[File:Seven Sisters (oil companies).jpg|thumb|The [[Seven Sisters (oil companies)]].]] [[Image:GasStationHiroshima.jpg|thumb|right|Petrol station in [[Hiroshima]], [[Japan]].]]
"'''Fossil fuels lobby'''" is the [[umbrella term]] used to name the [[Lobbying|paid representatives]] of large [[fossil fuel]] ([[petroleum industry|oil]], [[Natural gas|gas]], [[coal]]) and [[Electric utility|electric utilities]] corporations who attempt to influence governmental policy. So-called [[Big Oil]] companies such as [[ExxonMobil]], [[Royal Dutch Shell]], [[BP]], [[Total S.A.]], [[Chevron Corporation]], and [[ConocoPhillips]] are amongst the largest [[corporation]]s associated with the fossil fuels lobby. [[General Electric]], [[Southern Company]], [[FirstEnergy|First Energy]], and the [[Edison Electric Institute]] are also among the most influential electric utilities corporations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gasandoil.com/goc/main.htm|title=Alexander's Gas & Oil Connections = Welcome / Main entry page|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420005819/http://gasandoil.com/goc/main.htm|archivedate=20 April 2011|df=}}</ref> However, [[Electric power industry|electric companies]] and big oil and gas companies are consistently not among the ten highest-spending lobbyists – the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]] is currently #1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/top.php?showYear=2014&indexType=s|title=Lobbying|publisher=|accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref> By sector, "Energy/Nat Resource" comes fifth, behind "Misc Business", "Finance/Insur/RealEst", Health and "Communic/Electronics".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/top.php?showYear=2014&indexType=c|title=Lobbying Spending Database - OpenSecrets|author=|date=|website=www.opensecrets.org}}</ref>
==Influence of the energy lobby in the United States== {{Update|section|date=February 2018}} [[File:DC-Climate-March-2017-1510576 (33551760363).jpg|thumb|Placard "Separate oil and state", at the [[People's Climate March (2017)]].]]
In the [[United States elections, 2000|2000 elections]], over $34 million was contributed, with 78% of that money going to Republicans. In 2004, oil and gas companies contributed over $25 million to political campaigns, donating 80% of that money to Republicans. In the [[United States general election, 2006|2006 election]] cycle, oil and gas companies contributed over $19 million to political campaigns. 82% of that money went to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidates, while the remaining 18% went to [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]]. Electric utilities also heavily favor Republicans; their contributions have recently ranged between $15–20 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/indus.asp?cycle=2006&ind=E08|title=Electric Utilities|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421041153/http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/indus.asp?cycle=2006&ind=E08|archivedate=21 April 2008|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/indus.asp?cycle=2006&ind=E01|title=Oil & Gas|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421041147/http://www.opensecrets.org/industries/indus.asp?cycle=2006&ind=E01|archivedate=21 April 2008|df=}}</ref> From 2003–06, the energy lobby also contributed $58.3 million to [[U.S. state|state]]-level campaigns. By comparison, [[alternative energy]] interests contributed around half a million dollars in the same time period.<ref>http://www.followthemoney.org/press/Reports/200705231.pdf</ref>
During the [[United States elections, 2012|United States elections in 2012]] which includes the [[United States presidential election, 2012|presidential election]] there was much spending by the lobbies.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/14/us/politics/fossil-fuel-industry-opens-wallet-to-defeat-obama.html ''Fossil Fuel Industry Ads Dominate TV Campaign''] September 13, 2012</ref>
==Criticisms== [[File:AirPollutionSource.jpg|thumb|Refineries owned by energy companies produce large amounts of [[air pollutants|environmental emissions]].]]
===Environmental impact of represented companies=== Many of the most influential members of the energy lobby are among the top [[pollution|polluters]] in the United States, with Conoco, Exxon, and General Electric ranking in the top six.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peri.umass.edu/Toxic-100-Table.265.0.html |title=PERI: Home |publisher= |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001071549/http://www.peri.umass.edu/Toxic-100-Table.265.0.html |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> According to the [[Environmental Integrity Project]], a [[nonpartisan]], [[nonprofit]] organization established in March 2002 by former attorneys at the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]], “Companies like ExxonMobil and [[Sunoco]] keep reporting record profits while increasing emissions or more cancer causing chemicals from their refineries.”<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.environmentalintegrity.org/pubs/020807%20TRI%20EIP%20news%20rews%20release%20FINAL%20_2_.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070508125049/http://www.environmentalintegrity.org/pubs/020807%20TRI%20EIP%20news%20rews%20release%20FINAL%20_2_.pdf |archivedate=2007-05-08 |df= }}</ref> The energy lobby is criticized for using its influence to block or dilute [[climate change legislation|legislation regarding global climate change]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpolicy.org/socecon/envronmt/tncwarm.htm|title=Global Warming & the Energy Corporations|author=Administrator|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref>
===Governmental influence in the United States=== {{Update|section|date=February 2018}} Various [[scandal]]s involving prominent politicians have drawn attention to the close links between the energy lobby and the [[U.S. government]], particularly the influence wielded by the energy lobby in the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]]. Lobbying continued after the Bush administration.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2016/07/22/oil-lobby-paid-washington-post-and-atlantic-to-host-climate-change-deniers-at-rnc/ |title=Oil Lobby Paid Washington Post and Atlantic to Host Climate-Change Deniers at RNC |last1=Emmons |first1=Alex |date=21 July 2016 |website=theintercept.com |publisher=[[The Intercept]] |access-date=24 July 2016}}</ref> In June 2005, documents emerged that revealed that the Bush administration had consulted Exxon regarding its stance on the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', "In briefing papers given before meetings to the U.S. [[Under Secretary of State for Democracy and Global Affairs]], [[Paula Dobriansky]], between 2001 and 2004, the administration is found thanking [[Exxon]] executives for the company's ‘active involvement’ in helping to determine climate change policy, and also seeking its advice on what climate change policies the company might find acceptable."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/climatechange/story/0,12374,1501646,00.html|title=Revealed: how oil giant influenced Bush|author=Environment editor|newspaper=the Guardian|accessdate=6 April 2015|date=2005-06-08}}</ref> In November 2005, documents revealed that Vice President [[Dick Cheney]]’s [[Energy Task Force]] met with executives from large oil companies, although chief executives of those companies denied involvement before the [[U.S. Senate|Senate]] Energy and Commerce committees. [[Environmentalism|Environmentalists]] were not allowed access to the Energy Task Force’s activities, which was responsible for developing a national energy policy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/11/15/AR2005111501842.html|title=Document Says Oil Chiefs Met With Cheney Task Force|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015|date=2005-11-16|last1=Blum|first1=Dana Milbank Justin}}</ref><ref>[[Natural Resources Defense Council]] [http://www.nrdc.org/air/energy/taskforce/tfinx.asp (NRDC)'s Review of the Bush Administration Energy Task Force Records<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Oil companies also participated with [[Dick Cheney]]'s task force in a discussion of [[Iraq]]i oilfields, refineries and other energy infrastructure, and two charts detailing Iraqi oil and gas projects, and “Foreign Suitors for Iraqi Oilfield Contracts.” The documents are dated two years before the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], and six months before the [[September 11 attacks|September 11 attacks (9/11)]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Cheney Energy Task Force Documents Feature Map of Iraqi Oil Fields | url = http://www.judicialwatch.org/press-room/press-releases/cheney-energy-task-force-documents-feature-map-of-iraqi-oilfields/ | publisher = [[Judicial Watch]] | date = 2003-07-17 | accessdate = 2013-11-14 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Maps and Charts of Iraqi Oil Fields | url = http://www.judicialwatch.org/bulletins/maps-and-charts-of-iraqi-oil-fields/ | publisher = [[Judicial Watch]] | date = 2012-02-14 | accessdate = 2013-11-14 }}</ref>
===Global influence=== {{Reduced pull quote|1=right |2=Those corporations that continue to invest in new fossil fuel exploration, new fossil fuel exploitation, are really in flagrant breach of their fiduciary duty because the science is abundantly clear that this is something we can no longer do. |3=[[Christiana Figueres]]|4=executive secretary of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]<ref>Cited in [[Tim Flannery]], ''Atmosphere of Hope. Solutions to the Climate Crisis'', [[Penguin Books]], 2015, pp. 123–24 ({{ISBN|9780141981048}}).</ref>}}
The energy lobby has a history of conflict with international interests and democratic [[global governance]]. According to the [[International Sustainable Energy Organization]] for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency the second [[World Climate Conference]] "was sabotaged by the USA and oil lobbies"<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.uniseo.org/blueprint.html|title=International Sustainable Energy Organization|author=|date=|website=www.uniseo.org}}</ref> whereupon [[UNISEO]] proceeded to set up a [[Global Energy Charter]] "which protects life, health, climate and the biosphere from emissions." According to the organization, these same "reactionary energy lobby groups tried to boycott this Charter with the help from oil- and [[Coal-mining region|coal]]-producing nations and succeeded to keep energy out of the Rio Conference on Environment & Development ([[Earth Summit]]) in 1992, to continue this game in all Climate Conferences in [[Berlin]], [[Kyoto]], [[The Hague]] and [[Marrakech]], where the USA boycotted the [[Kyoto protocol]] and still ignores the Charter."<ref name=autogenerated1 />
During the 14th session of the [[United Nations]] [[Commission on Sustainable Development]], according to the [[International Institute for Sustainable Development]] ''Bulletin'', "One minister is said to have challenged the North’s [[renewable energy]] lobby with the words: why not “light up” the dark zones of the world by “extinguishing some of the candles” in yours?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iisd.ca/download/asc/enb05237e.txt|title=IISD Bulletin|author=|date=|website=iisd.ca}}</ref>

The '''Freedom to Speak Up Review''' was a review into [[whistleblowing]] in the [[NHS in England]]. It was announced on 24 June 2014 and it was chaired by [[Robert Francis (barrister)|Sir Robert Francis]].<ref>Sophie Borland Daily Mail (25 June 2014) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2668566/NHS-gripped-culture-fear-Inquiry-whistleblowing-set-barrister-investigated-Mid-Staffs.html NHS is still gripped by a culture of fear: Inquiry into whistleblowing set up by barrister who investigated Mid Staffs]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomtospeakup.org.uk/|title=Freedom to Speak Up Review|website=webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20150218150343/https://freedomtospeakup.org.uk/|archivedate=2015-02-18|df=}}</ref> The review was originally expected to report in November 2014 but took longer because of a huge volume of input material: 17,500 online responses and 600 postal responses.<ref>Sophie Borland Daily Mail (21 January 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2919200/Probe-NHS-whistleblowers-swamped-18-000-replies.html Probe into NHS whistleblowers is swamped by 18,000 replies: Officials tried to push back report after being deluged with comments by concerned staff]</ref>
The report was published on 11 February 2015.<ref name="Guardian 11Feb2105">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/feb/11/nhs-whistleblowers-report-offers-no-prescription-cover-up-culture |title=NHS whistleblowers report offers no prescription for ending cover-up culture |first=Denis |last=Campbell |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref>
==Recommendations== Francis outlined twenty principles and associated actions, then concluded by making just two recommendations:<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://cri.sagepub.com/content/20/6/128.short |title=Francis’s ‘‘Freedom to Speak Up’’ review: An openness and transparency revolution or just another report? |first=Peter |last=Walsh |journal=Clinical Risk |date= November 2014 |volume=20 |issue=6 |page=128 |doi=10.1177/1356262215575958}}</ref> # for all NHS organisations and regulators to implement all the principles and actions; # for the Secretary of State to review progress annually.
The twenty principles to allow a consistent approach to raising concerns, while still allowing some flexibility, included:<ref name=Parry>Lizzie Parry Daily Mail (11 February 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2948871/NHS-staff-scared-speak-poor-care-Climate-fear-leaves-worried-bullied-lose-job-speak-up.html Climate of fear leaves NHS whistleblowers 'on the brink of suicide' says report but campaigners warn new measures to protect workers 'don't go far enough']</ref> * Culture of raising concerns - to make raising issues a part of normal routine business of any well-led NHS organisation. * Culture free from bullying - freedom of staff to speak out relies on staff being able to work in a culture which is free from bullying. * Training - every member of staff should receive training in their trust's approach to raising concerns and in receiving and acting on them. * Support - all NHS trusts should ensure there is a dedicated person to whom concerns can be easily reported and without formality, a "Freedom to Speak Up Guardian" . * Support to find alternative employment in the NHS - where a worker who has raised a concern cannot, as a result, continue their role, the NHS should help them seek an alternative job.
==Reactions== Many campaigners claimed that the recommendations did not go far enough.<ref name=Parry/><ref>Patrick Sawer, Laura Donnelly The Telegraph (11 February 2015) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/news/11405430/Whistleblowing-Its-still-not-safe-for-us-to-speak-out.html Whistleblowing: 'It's still not safe for us to speak out']</ref><ref> Sophie Borland, Claire Ellicott, Daniel Martin Daily Mail (12 February 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2949934/Whistleblower-whitewash-Health-staff-dare-speak-not-protected-says-report.html Whistleblower whitewash: Health staff who dare to speak out will still not be protected, says report]</ref><ref name="Guardian 11Feb2105"/>
==National Guardian== In January 2016 [[Eileen Sills]] was appointed as the first Freedom to Speak Up National Guardian for the NHS.<ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dame-eileen-sills Dame Eileen Sills] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126120604/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dame-eileen-sills |date=2016-01-26 }} [[Care Quality Commission]] website 7 Jan 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/cqc-appoints-first-national-guardian-freedom-speak-nhs CQC appoints first National Guardian for the freedom to speak up in the NHS] Care Quality Commission website 7 Jan 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/national-freedom-speak-guardian-nhs The National Freedom to Speak Up Guardian for the NHS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126122813/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/national-freedom-speak-guardian-nhs |date=2016-01-26 }} Care Quality Commission website 7 Jan 2016</ref> She resigned two months later, citing that she did not have sufficient time to combine this role with her other work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/mar/08/nhs-national-guardian-resigns-post-eileen-sills|title=NHS's first 'national guardian' resigns after two months|first=Ben|last=Quinn|date=7 March 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> Dr Henrietta Hughes was appointed as the second Freedom to Speak Up National Guardian in July 2016.<ref>https://www.cqc.org.uk/news/releases/new-national-guardian-appointed-lead-nhs-speaking-freely-safely</ref>
==See also== * [[Eileen Chubb]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=Giustizia e Libertà | image= Logo of Giustizia e Liberta.svg | image_size = 150 |caption=Emblem of Giustizia e Libertà |dates=1929–1945 |country= |allegiance=Italian anti-fascist resistance |type=Partisans |role= |size= |command_structure=[[Action Party (Italy)|Action Party]] |garrison= |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=[[Spanish Civil War]], [[Italian Campaign (World War II)]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |disbanded= <!-- Commanders --> |commander1= |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |notable_commanders=[[Carlo Rosselli]], [[Ferruccio Parri]], [[Giorgio Bocca]] <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} {{expand Italian|date=November 2011|Giustizia e Libertà}}
'''Giustizia e Libertà''' ({{IPA-it|dʒuˈstittsja e liberˈta}}; {{lang-en|Justice and Freedom}}) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[anti-fascist]] [[resistance movement]], active from 1929 to 1945.<ref>James D. Wilkinson. ''The Intellectual Resistance Movement in Europe''. Harvard University Press, 1981. Pp. 224.</ref> The movement was founded by [[Carlo Rosselli]].<ref>James D. Wilkinson. ''The Intellectual Resistance Movement in Europe''. Harvard University Press, 1981. Pp. 224.</ref> [[Ferruccio Parri]] – who later became [[Prime Minister of Italy]], and [[Sandro Pertini]] – who later became [[President of Italy]] were among the movement's leaders.<ref>Stanislao G. Pugliese. ''Carlo Rosselli: socialist heretic and antifascist exile''. Harvard University Press, 1999. Pp. 51.</ref>
== Italian anti-fascist organization (1929–1940) == [[File:Flag of Giustizia e Liberta.svg|thumb|left|Flag of ''Giustizia e Libertà'']] [[File:Bandiera giustizia e liberta.jpg|thumb|right|Sleeve emblem ''Giustizia e Libertà'' Partisans]] The anti-fascist organisation ''Giustizia e Libertà'' was founded in [[Paris]] in 1929 by the Italian refugees [[Carlo Rosselli]], [[Emilio Lussu]], [[Alberto Tarchiani]], and [[Ernesto Rossi (politician)|Ernesto Rossi]]. They began to organise the resistance against [[Italian Fascism]], forming clandestine groups in Italy and setting up an intense propaganda campaign, publishing under Lussu's maxim: "Insorgere! Risorgere!" (Rebel! Revive!). [[Carlo Levi]] was named a director of the Italian branch along with [[Leone Ginzburg]], a Russian Jew from Odessa who had emigrated with his parents to [[Turin]].
''Giustizia e Libertà'' was committed to militant action to fight the Fascist regime; the movement saw [[Benito Mussolini]] as a ruthless murderer who himself deserved to be killed as punishment.<ref>Spencer Di Scala. ''Italian socialism: between politics and history''. Boston, Massachusetts, USA: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1996. Pp. 87.</ref> Various early schemes were designed by the movement in the 1930s to assassinate Mussolini, including one dramatic plan of using an aircraft to drop a bomb on [[Piazza Venezia]] where Mussolini resided.<ref>Spencer Di Scala. ''Italian socialism: between politics and history''. Boston, Massachusetts, USA: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1996. Pp. 87.</ref>
After a series of arrests and trials, (including the conviction of Carlo Levi) the movement was forced in 1930 to curb this activity. In 1931 the organisation joined the ''[[Concentrazione Antifascista Italiana]]'' (Anti-Fascist Concentration), and in 1932 began promoting a plan that aimed not for the restoration of the pre-fascist political order but for a new [[social democracy]] centered around a [[Republic|Republican state]]. It called for economic rights and administrative decentralisation. The group produced its own journal, on which Salvatorelli, De Ruggiero and others collaborated. This journal reflected the politics of the group's leaders, who sought to distance themselves from [[communism]] and the [[Italian Communist Party]]. At the outbreak of the [[Spanish Civil War]] in 1936, the organisation formed its own volunteer brigades to support the [[Second Spanish Republic|Spanish Republic]].
[[Carlo Rosselli]] and [[Camillo Berneri]] headed a mixed volunteer unit of anarchist, liberal, socialist, and communist Italians on the [[Aragon]] front, whose military successes included a victory against Francoist forces in the [[Battle of Monte Pelato]]. They popularised the slogan: "Oggi in Spagna, domani in Italia" (Today in Spain, tomorrow in Italy). In 1937, Camillo Berneri was killed by communist forces during a purge of anarchists in Barcelona. With the fall of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Spanish Republic]] in 1939, ''Giustizia e Libertà'' partisans were forced to flee back to France.
Several members of Giustizia e Libertà, including Aldo Garosci, Alberto Cianca, and Alberto Tarchiani, then emigrated to the [[United States]], where they helped form the antifascist [[Mazzini Society]] to promote a liberal democratic republic for Italy. They sailed to England in 1943 and set in operation the clandestine Giustizia e Libertà radio to denounce both Fascism and the monarchy for its complicity in Fascism.
== The military arm of Partito d'Azione (1942–1945) == ''Giustizia e Libertà'' was forced to cease public operations when German troops [[Battle of France|occupied France]] in 1940. Its members were dispersed, but largely reconstituted themselves as the [[Action Party (Italy)|Action Party]] (''Partito d'Azione'') in German-occupied Italy following the [[Armistice with Italy|Armistice of 1943]]. The military arms of the organisation, the partisan brigades, were still referred to as ''Giustizia e Libertà''.
After 8 September 1943, partisan units under the ''Giustizia e Libertà'' banner formed after the Italian capitulation to Allied forces and the creation of the [[Italian Social Republic]] [[puppet state]] of Nazi Germany. As the largest non-Communist partisan groups, they benefited from provisions and training that were denied to other units by the western Allies. Among the group's best known commanders was [[Ferruccio Parri]], who, using the nom-de-guerre "Maurizio," represented the Action Party in the Military Committee of the National Liberation Committee of Northern Italy ([[CLNAI]]). Centres of activity included [[Turin]], [[Florence]], and [[Milan]], where a resistance cell was headed by [[Ugo La Malfa]], [[Ferruccio Parri]], and [[Adolfo Tino]]. Parri was arrested in Milan and turned over to the Germans, but he was later exchanged for German officials imprisoned by the partisans. He returned in time to take part in the conclusive phase of the resistance and in the Milan uprising.
The writer [[Primo Levi]] was a member of the [[Action Party (Italy)|Action Party]] partisan group in [[Aosta Valley]]. He was captured by fascist forces in 1943, handed over to the Germans in 1944, and deported to [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz III (Monowitz)]].
''Giustizia e Libertà'' brigades were regarded as professional military units, which drew fighters from every social class. In the twenty months of the war, their units sustained 4,500 overall casualties, among them the greater portion of their leaders.
